abstract.p: Transcription factors (TFs) are proteins crucial for regulating gene expression. Effective regulation requires the TFs to rapidly bind to their correct target, enabling the cell to respond efficiently to stimuli such as nutrient availability or the presence of toxins. However, the search process is hindered by slow diffusive movement and the presence of ‘false’ targets – DNA segments that are similar to the true target. In eukaryotic cells, most TFs contain an intrinsically disordered region (IDR), which is commonly assumed to behave as a long, flexible polymeric tail composed of hundreds of amino acids. Recent experimental findings indicate that the IDR of certain TFs plays a pivotal role in the search process. However, the principles underlying the IDR’s role remain unclear. Here, we reveal key design principles of the IDR related to TF binding affinity and search time. Our results demonstrate that the IDR significantly enhances both of these aspects. Furthermore, our model shows good agreement with experimental results, and we propose further experiments to validate the model’s predictions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Transcription factors (TFs) are fundamental proteins that regulate gene expression: they bind to specific DNA sequences to control gene transcription Latchman, 1997; they respond adaptively to various cellular signals, thereby modulating gene expression Mitchell and Tjian, 1989; Ptashne and Gann, 1997; they guide processes such as cell differentiation and development, and their malfunctions are often linked to disease onset (Lambert et al., 2018; Stadhouders et al., 2019). The principles of gene regulation were first formulated in the 1960s through pioneering studies of the E. coli Lac operon (Jacob and Monod, 1961), establishing that the regulation mechanism is via the binding of a TF to the regulatory DNA regions associated with the genes, the TF’s target. Effective regulation requires TFs to have sufficient binding affinity and a binding rate comparable to cellular processes. Despite these decades of research, the factors determining the binding strength and search efficiency of eukaryotic TFs remain incompletely understood (Ferrie et al., 2022; Jonas et al., 2025). In eukaryotic cells, besides having a DNA-binding domain (DBD), approximately 80% of TFs also have one or more intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs), which lack a stable 3D structure and can be assumed as flexible, unstructured polymers, hundreds of amino acids (AAs) in length (Liu et al., 2006; Fuxreiter et al., 2011; Guo et al., 2011; Wright and Dyson, 2015). Eukaryotic DBDs often exhibit weaker affinity to their recognition sequences compared to their bacterial counterparts, indicating that IDRs are necessary for achieving stable binding (Garcia et al., 2021). However, IDRs are challenging to study because their functions can be maintained despite rapid sequence divergence, complicating traditional sequence-based analyses (Brown et al., 2010; Zarin et al., 2019). Molecular dynamics simulations suggest that IDRs play a significant role in promoting target recognition (Vuzman and Levy, 2010), by increasing the area of effective interaction between the TF and the DNA. Upon binding, the search problem becomes effectively a one-dimensional diffusion process (Vuzman and Levy, 2012). Recent in vivo experiments done in yeast also suggest that IDRs could take a key part in guiding TFs to the DNA regions containing their targets (Brodsky et al., 2020; Kumar et al., 2023). Truncation studies of IDRs in various TFs have demonstrated that removing these regions often results in reduced binding affinity, suggesting they contribute significantly to stabilizing TF-DNA interactions (Brodsky et al., 2020). Different mechanisms have been proposed in the literature to explain IDR contributions: some suggest non-specific electrostatic interactions (Iwahara et al., 2006), others propose phase separation that concentrates TFs near their targets (Boija et al., 2018), while a third view suggests specific IDR-DNA interactions analogous to those of structured domains (Chappleboim et al., 2024).

The problem of TF search has been widely studied, theoretically, albeit with the majority of works focusing on parameter regimes relevant for bacteria. One important mechanism is that of facilitated diffusion, in which the TF performs 1D diffusion along the DNA and at any given moment can fall off and perform 3D diffusion until reattaching to the DNA (a 3D excursion). The 1D diffusion along the DNA and the 3D excursions alternate until the TF finds its target. This mechanism is well characterized theoretically (Berg et al., 1981; Berg and von Hippel, 1987; Slutsky and Mirny, 2004; Mirny et al., 2009; Li et al., 2009; Bénichou et al., 2011; Sheinman et al., 2012) and supported by experiments in E. coli (Hammar et al., 2012). However, due to the significant structural differences, including larger genome size and chromatin structure, the facilitated diffusion mechanism cannot explain the fast search times observed in eukaryotes, and a qualitatively different mechanism is required (Dror et al., 2016; Jana et al., 2021; Ferrie et al., 2022; Kumar et al., 2023; Wagh et al., 2023).

Here, we attempt to address the fundamental question of how IDRs can enhance the binding affinity of the TFs and speed up their search process and to discover the associated design principles in eukaryotes. The problem of binding affinity (binding probability) exhibits the classical trade-off between energy and entropy: on one hand, the binding of IDR to the DNA is energetically favorable. On the other hand, this binding leads to constraints on the positions of the IDR (pinned to the DNA at the points of attachment), which leads to a reduction in the entropy associated with the possible polymer conformations – hence an increase in the free energy of the system. Therefore, the effects of the disordered tail on affinity are non-trivial, leading to physical problems reminiscent of those associated with the well-studied problem of DNA unzipping (Danilowicz et al., 2004). We find that the binding probability increases dramatically for TFs having IDRs for a broad parameter regime. The optimal search process consists of one round of 3D-1D search, where at first the TF performs 3D diffusion and then binds the antenna and performs 1D diffusion until finding its target, rarely unbinding for another 3D excursion. This process is presented in Figure 1a and c. We obtain an expression for the search time that shows good agreement with our numerical results.

sec.title: Binding probability of the TF from the equilibrium approach
sec.p: The experiment described in Brodsky et al., 2020 studied the binding affinity of wild-type and mutated TFs to their corresponding targets. They found that shortening the IDR length results in weaker affinity. To qualitatively model the binding affinity of a TF to its target, we utilize a well-known physical model of polymers, the Rouse Model (Prince, 1953; Doi and Edwards, 1988; used in the subsequent dynamical section as well). See Materials and methods. We note that our conclusions do not hinge on this choice, and our results hold also when using other polymer models (see Appendix Appendix 1). Broad applicability of probability density f(r,l)\begin{document}$f(r,l)$\end{document}. Since the IDR is thought to recognize a relatively short flanking DNA sequence of the DBD target (Brodsky et al., 2020), we model a DNA segment as a straight-line ‘antenna’ region (Shimamoto, 1999; Hu and Shklovskii, 2007; Mirny et al., 2009; Castellanos et al., 2020), where the IDR targets reside. We assume that the interaction between TF and DNA outside the antenna region is negligible. Note that the interaction between IDR and DNA is a specific interaction, with genomic localization determined by multivalent interactions mediated by hydrophobic residues (Jonas et al., 2023; Mindel et al., 2024).

To gain an intuition into the binding probability of TF, we first study a TF with a single IDR site. From here on, energies will be measured in units of kBT\begin{document}$k_{B}T$\end{document}, to simplify our notation. We assume that the IDR has only one corresponding target. There are four possible states: neither the DBD nor the IDR is bound, the IDR is bound, the DBD is bound, and both are bound, which correspond to Pfree\begin{document}$P_{\rm free}$\end{document}, PIDR\begin{document}$P_{\rm IDR}$\end{document}, PDBD\begin{document}$P_{\rm DBD}$\end{document}, and Pboth\begin{document}$P_{\rm both}$\end{document}, respectively. The probability that the TF is bound at the DBD target is the sum of PDBD\begin{document}$P_{\rm DBD}$\end{document} and Pboth\begin{document}$P_{\rm both}$\end{document}. In thermal equilibrium, each of the 4 terms is given by the Boltzmann distribution, which can be solved analytically by integrating out the additional degrees of freedom associated with the polymer (Appendix 2. Derivation of the binding probability). To better understand the associated design principles, it will be helpful to compare this probability with that of a ‘simple’ TF (i.e. without the IDR), which we denote by Psimple\begin{document}$P_{\rm simple}$\end{document}. We find that:(1)PTFPsimple≈(1+P),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{P_{\rm TF}}{P_{{\rm simple}}} \approx (1+\mathcal{P}),$$\end{document}

where P\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}$\end{document} is an enhancement factor, governing the degree to which the IDR improved the binding affinity. Importantly, we find that:(2)P(EB,d,l0)=eEBV1f(d,l0),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal{P}(E_B,d,l_0)\,=\,e^{E_{B}}V_1f(d,l_{0}),$$\end{document}

where f(d,l0)=(32πl02)3/2exp⁡(−3d22l02)\begin{document}$f(d,l_{0})=\left(\frac{3}{2\pi l_{0}^{2}}\right)^{3/2}\exp{\left(-\frac{3d^{2} }{2l_{0}^{2}}\right)}$\end{document}, is the probability density, with units of inverse volume, V1\begin{document}$V_{1}$\end{document} is the targets’ volume, on the order of 1−10bp3\begin{document}${1-10\rm bp}^{3}$\end{document}, as shown in Figure 1c, −EB\begin{document}$-E_{B}$\end{document} is the binding energy for per IDR target (EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} is always positive), d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} is the distance between the DBD target and the IDR target, and l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} is the distance between the DBD and the IDR binding site on the TF (l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} and d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} are also the distances for neighboring IDR targets and neighboring IDR sites, respectively, in the case of multiple IDR targets and sites).

This shows that the presence of the IDR always increases the binding affinity since P\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}$\end{document} is always positive. However, the magnitude of enhancement can be negligible: For instance, even if EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} is large, the term f(d,l0)\begin{document}$f(d,l_{0})$\end{document}, associated with the entropic penalty (because the end-to-end distance is fixed, reducing the degrees of freedom compared to a free polymer), could lead to small values of P\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}$\end{document}.

The exponential decay of P\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}$\end{document} with d2\begin{document}$d^{2}$\end{document} (through the term f(d,l0)\begin{document}$f(d,l_{0})$\end{document}), indicates that placing the IDR targets close to the DBD target is preferable. However, due to physical limitations, d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} cannot be arbitrarily small and in reality will have a lower bound. Once d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} is fixed, P\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}$\end{document} is maximal at l0=d\begin{document}$l_{0}\,=\,d$\end{document}, as can be gleaned from Equation 2. This condition minimizes the free energy penalty associated with the entropic contribution of the term f(d,l0)\begin{document}$f(d,l_{0})$\end{document}.
As we shall see, this design principle is also intact when multiple IDR sites and targets are involved, which is the scenario we discuss next.

A priori, it is unclear whether having more binding sites (nb>1\begin{document}$n_{b} \gt 1$\end{document}) on the IDR or more targets (nt>1\begin{document}$n_{t}\,\gt \,1$\end{document}) on the DNA will be beneficial or not. We therefore sought to investigate how the binding affinity depends on these parameters, as well as the binding energy and positions of the targets and binding sites. This generalization requires taking into account all the possible number of bindings, n\begin{document}$n$\end{document} (ranging from 0 to min(nb,nt)\begin{document}$\min{\left(n_{b},n_{t}\right)}$\end{document}), and all possibilities for binding orientations for each n\begin{document}$n$\end{document}, (nbn)(ntn)n!\begin{document}${n_{b}\choose n}{n_{t}\choose n}n!$\end{document} distinct configurations in total. For each of them, we may analytically integrate out the polymer degrees of freedom and calculate explicitly the contribution to the partition function (Appendix 2. Derivation of the binding probability). Summing these terms together, numerically, allows us to explore how the different parameters affect the binding specificity, which we describe next. To characterize the binding affinity, we resort again to the ratio Q≡PTF/Psimple\begin{document}$Q\equiv P_{\rm TF}/P_{\rm simple}$\end{document}, measuring the effectiveness of the binding in comparison to the case with no IDRs. The length of TFs in our considerations, which varies with nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document}, is comparable to that in experiments (Brodsky et al., 2020).

We find the design principle: l0=d\begin{document}$l_{0}=d$\end{document}, identical to what we showed for the case of a single IDR binding site. Specifically, Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document} is maximal at l0∼d\begin{document}$l_{0}\sim d$\end{document} for all combinations of nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} and nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document}. Figure 2a displays this principle for several combinations of nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} and nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document}. All combinations are provided in Appendix 3—figure 1. This is plausible since for the IDR to be bound to the DNA at multiple places without paying a large entropic penalty, the distance between target sites should be compatible with the distance between binding sites.

sec.p: We therefore set l0=d\begin{document}$l_{0}\,=\,d$\end{document} and search for other design principles. Figure 2b shows a heatmap of Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document} varying with nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} and nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document}. At large nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document}, as nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} increases, the value of PTF\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}$\end{document} exhibits an initial substantial increase, followed by a gradual rise until it reaches saturation (shown explicitly in Appendix 4—figure 1).

A similar behavior is also observed when varying the value of nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document}. (When nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document} exceeds nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document}, the contribution from the states where the IDR is bound but the DBD is unbound increases with increasing nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document}, which slightly lowers PTF\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}$\end{document}; see Appendix 4—figure 1.)

In fact, the heatmap shown in Figure 2b shows that the value of PTF\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}$\end{document} is governed, approximately, by the minimum of nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} and nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document} (this is reflected in the nearly symmetrical ‘L-shapes’ of the contours). This places strong constraints on the optimization and suggests that there will be little advantage in increasing the value of either nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} or nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document} beyond the point nb=nt\begin{document}$n_{b}\,=\,n_{t}$\end{document}, revealing another design principle (under the assumption that it is preferable to have smaller values of nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} and nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document} for a given level of affinity, in order to minimize the cellular costs involved).

We verify this principle holds at additional values of EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}. Figure 2c shows that the contours corresponding to PTF=0.9\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}\,=\,0.9$\end{document} at varying values of EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} all take an approximate symmetrical L-shape, thus supporting the design principle nb=nt\begin{document}$n_{b}=n_{t}$\end{document}. For a given EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}, we denote the optimal values as nb∗=nt∗\begin{document}$n_{b}^{*}\,=\,n_{t}^{*}$\end{document}, and show them as hexagrams in the plot.

We further find that nb∗\begin{document}$n_{b}^{*}$\end{document} decreases with increasing EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}, as displayed in the inset. These relationships also hold at PTF=0.5\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}\,=\,0.5$\end{document} (Appendix 5. Robustness of the relationships: nb∗∼nt∗\begin{document}$n_{b}^{*}\sim n_{t}^{*}$\end{document} and nb∗\begin{document}$n_{b}^{*}$\end{document} decreases with increasing EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}).

We examine the variation of Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document} with respect to EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} while keeping nb=nt\begin{document}$n_{b}\,=\,n_{t}$\end{document} constant. In Figure 2d, as the binding energy EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} increases, Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document} increases from a value of ∼1\begin{document}$\sim 1$\end{document} to its saturation value, 1/Psimple\begin{document}$1/P_{\rm simple}$\end{document}, in a switch-like manner: that is, there is a characteristic energy scale, Eth\begin{document}$E_{\rm th}$\end{document}. To estimate Eth\begin{document}$E_{\rm th}$\end{document}, when Q≪1/Psimple\begin{document}$Q\,\ll\,1/P_{\rm simple}$\end{document} (i.e. PTF≪1\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}\,\ll\,1$\end{document}), we approximate the expression of Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document} as:(3)Q≈1+Σn=1nbΣorn∏i=1nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle Q\approx 1+\Sigma_{n=1}^{n_b} \Sigma_{\rm orn}\prod_{i=1}^{n}\,\mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i}),$$\end{document}

where lorn,i\begin{document}$l_{{\rm orn},i}$\end{document} and rorn,i\begin{document}$r_{{\rm orn},i}$\end{document} denote the segment length between two adjacent bound sites and the distance associated with their respective targets, respectively, and ‘orn’ represents the orientation of the given configuration (Appendix 2. Derivation of the binding probability). Equation 3 reduces to Equation 1 when nt=nb=1\begin{document}$n_{t}\,=\,n_{b}\,=\,1$\end{document}. To substantially increase Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document}, the configuration that contributes the most to Q\begin{document}$Q$\end{document}, would satisfy (P(EB,d,d))nb≫1\begin{document}$(\mathcal{P}(E_{B},d,d))^{n_{b}}\,\gg\,1$\end{document}. Thus, the characteristic energy Eth\begin{document}$E_{\rm th}$\end{document} could be estimated using the formula P(Eth,d,d)=1\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}(E_{\rm th},d,d)=1$\end{document}, resulting in:(4)Eth=32[ln⁡(2π3ϕ2)+1],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E_{\rm th} =\frac{3}{2}\left[\ln(\frac{2\pi}{3\phi^2})+1\right],$$\end{document}

where ϕ=V11/3/d\begin{document}$\phi\,=\,V_{1}^{1/3}/d$\end{document} represents the proportion of IDR targets within the antenna. Equation 4 is a direct consequence of the energy-entropy trade-off. Increasing ϕ\begin{document}$\phi$\end{document} leads to a decrease in entropy loss due to binding the IDR, subsequently reducing the demands on binding energy. Given that ϕ2=0.02\begin{document}$\phi^{2}=0.02$\end{document}, Eth\begin{document}$E_{\rm th}$\end{document} is about 8.5kBT\begin{document}$8.5k_{B}T$\end{document}. The vertical dashed line in Figure 2d, obtained from Equation 4, effectively captures the region of significant increase for large values of nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document}. Hence, we obtain the third design principle: EB>Eth\begin{document}$E_{B} \gt E_{\rm th}$\end{document}, which ensures the significant binding advantage of TFs with IDRs.

So far, we have found that the binding design principles for TFs with IDRs are as follows: (i) target distance d\begin{document}$d$\end{document} should be as small as possible, (ii) IDR segment binding distance l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} should be comparable to d\begin{document}$d$\end{document}, (iii) it is preferable to have fewer binding sites nb∗\begin{document}$n_{b}^{*}$\end{document} and binding targets nt∗\begin{document}$n_{t}^{*}$\end{document} as the binding strength EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} increases, with nb∗∼nt∗\begin{document}$n_{b}^{*}\,\sim\,n_{t}^{*}$\end{document}, and (iv) should be larger than a threshold that solely depends on the proportion ϕ\begin{document}$\phi$\end{document} of IDR targets within the antenna, as indicated by Equation 4. In our estimation, with ϕ2=0.02\begin{document}$\phi^{2}=0.02$\end{document}, we obtain Eth≈8.5kBT\begin{document}$E_{\rm th}\approx 8.5k_{B}T$\end{document}. The above principles have also been validated in scenarios involving Poisson statistics of binding site distances and target distances, thus indicating their robust applicability (Appendix 6—figure 1).

sec.title: Search time of the TF from the dynamics
sec.p: In this section, we study the design principles of the TF search time, a dynamic process. Here, we confine the TF with n~≡nb+1\begin{document}$\tilde{n}\,\equiv\,n_{b}\,+\,1$\end{document} sites (nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} IDR sites and one DBD site) to a sphere of radius R\begin{document}$R$\end{document}, the cell nucleus, and use over-damped coarse-grained molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. The sites and targets interact via a short-range interaction. The DBD target with a radius a\begin{document}$a$\end{document} is placed at the sphere’s center. See the sketch in Figure 1a. Once the DBD finds its target, the search ends. We denote the mean total search time (i.e. the mean first passage time, MFPT), as ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document}. We estimate it by averaging 500 simulations, each starting from an equilibrium configuration of the TF at a random position in the nucleus. Simulation details are provided in the Materials and Methods section.

By conducting comprehensive simulations of ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} across various parameter values of L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}, EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}, and n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document}, we were able to identify its minimum value, which is approximately at L∗=300bp\begin{document}$L^{*}\,=\,300\rm bp$\end{document}, EB∗=11\begin{document}$E_{B}^{*}\,=\,11$\end{document}, and n~∗=4\begin{document}$\tilde{n}^{*}\,=\,4$\end{document} for R=500bp≈1/6μm\begin{document}$R\,=\,500\rm bp\,\approx\,1/6\rm\mu m$\end{document}. Here, one base pair (bp\begin{document}$\rm bp$\end{document}) is equal to 0.34nm\begin{document}$0.34\rm nm$\end{document}. To speed up the simulations, we utilized several computational tricks, including adaptive time steps and treating the TF as a point particle when it is far from the antenna (see Materials and methods). Despite this, the simulations require 105 CPU hours due to the IDR trapped in the binding targets on the antenna, which results in the slow dynamics as found in the previous simulation works (Vuzman and Levy, 2010; Marcovitz and Levy, 2013). The probability distribution function (pdf) of individual search times exponentially decays with a typical time equal to ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document}, see inset of Figure 3. This indicates that ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} provides a good characterization of the search time.

It means that the optimal search process is a single round of 3D diffusion followed by 1D diffusion along the antenna. In Appendix 8, a single round of 3D-1D search is typically the case in the optimal search process., by analytically calculating the mean total search time using a coarse-grained model, we find that a single round of 3D-1D search is typically the case in the optimal search process. Note that our model differs profoundly from the conventional facilitated diffusion (FD) model in bacteria: In the latter, the TF is assumed to bind non-specifically to the DNA. Within our model, the antenna length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} can be tuned by changing the placement of the IDR targets on the DNA, making it an adjustable parameter rather than the entire genome length. As opposed to the FD model, which requires numerous rounds of DNA binding-unbinding to achieve minimal search time, within our model, the minimal search time is achieved for a single round of 3D and 1D search.

Interestingly, when we observe the motion of a TF along the antenna, IDR sites behave like ‘tentacles’, as illustrated in Figure 1c, constantly binding and unbinding from the DNA. We refer to this 1D walk as ‘octopusing’, inspired by the famous ‘reptation’ motion in entangled polymers suggested by de Gennes (de Gennes and Leger, 1982; see Video 1). We note that previous numerical studies Vuzman and Levy, 2010; Vuzman and Levy, 2012 used comprehensive, coarse-grained, MD simulations to demonstrate that including heterogeneously distributed binding sites on the IDR could facilitate intersegmental transfer between different regions of the DNA, which is reminiscent of our octopusing scenario.

sec.p: The mean 3D search time, t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document}, and the mean 1D search time, t1D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 1D}$\end{document} are also shown in Figure 3. To evaluate t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document}, we take advantage of several insights: first, if the TF gyration radius, rp=n~/6l0\begin{document}$r_{p}\,=\,\sqrt{\tilde{n}/6}l_{0}$\end{document}, is comparable or larger than the distance between targets, d\begin{document}$d$\end{document}, we may consider the chain of targets as, effectively, a continuous antenna. Making the targets denser would hardly accelerate the search time, reminiscent of the well-known chemoreception problem where high efficiency is achieved even with low receptor coverage (Berg and Purcell, 1977). Second, when the distance between the TF and the antenna is smaller than rp\begin{document}$r_{p}$\end{document}, one of the binding sites on the TF would almost surely attach to the targets. This allows us to approximately map the problem to the MFPT of a particle hitting an extremely thin ellipsoid with long axis of length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} and radius rp\begin{document}$r_{p}$\end{document}, the solution of which is ln⁡(L/rp)/L\begin{document}$\ln(L/r_{p})/L$\end{document} (Berg, 2018). We find that this scaling captures well the dependence of t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document} on the parameters, with a prefactor α∼O(1)\begin{document}$\alpha\,\sim\,O(1)$\end{document}.

For the 1D search from a single particle picture, since the TF is unlikely to detach once it attaches, it performs a 1D random walk. So, taken together, the mean total search time is(5)ttotal=t3D+t1D≈αn~R3DLln⁡(L/rp)+βL2D,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle t_{\rm total}=t_{\rm 3D}+t_{\rm 1D}\approx\alpha\frac{\tilde{n} R^{3}}{D L}\ln(L/r_{p})+ \beta\frac{L^2}{D },$$\end{document}

where D\begin{document}$D$\end{document} is the 3D diffusion coefficient of one site. For a TF with n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document} sites, its 3D diffusion coefficient, D3\begin{document}$D_{3}$\end{document}, is D/n~\begin{document}$D/\tilde{n}$\end{document} and β\begin{document}$\beta$\end{document} are fitting parameters.

The semi-analytical formulas of t1D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 1D}$\end{document}, t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document}, and ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document}, denoted by the solid lines in Figure 3, agree well with the simulation results for α=0.5\begin{document}$\alpha\,=\,0.5$\end{document} and β=14.5\begin{document}$\beta\,=\,14.5$\end{document}.

The theoretical result for the time spent in 3D was originally calculated for a point searcher (Berg, 2018). In that case, a value of α=2/3\begin{document}$\alpha\,=\,2/3$\end{document} was obtained. β\begin{document}$\beta$\end{document} is larger at larger EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} (see Appendix 7. TF walking along the antenna once it attaches, and ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} vs. EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} and vs. n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document}).

We also examine the dependence of ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} on the key parameters EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} and n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document}, in the vicinity of the optimal parameters which minimize the total search time (Appendix 7. TF walking along the antenna once it attaches, and ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} vs. EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} and vs. n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document}). We find that the affinity of TFs to the antenna decreases rapidly with decreasing the IDR length (Brodsky et al., 2020) and EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}. Consequently, when n~<n~∗\begin{document}$\tilde{n}\,\lt \,\tilde{n}^{*}$\end{document} or EB<EB∗\begin{document}$E_{B}\,\lt \,E_{B}^{*}$\end{document}, multiple search rounds are needed to reach the DBD target, resulting in a significant escalation of ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document}. When n~>n~∗\begin{document}$\tilde{n}\,\gt \,\tilde{n}^{*}$\end{document}, ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document}, t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document}, and t1D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 1D}$\end{document} agree with Equation 5. When EB>EB∗\begin{document}$E_{B}\,\gt \,E_{B}^{*}$\end{document}, since t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document} is independent of EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}, the variation in ttoS7tal\begin{document}$t_{\rm toS7tal}$\end{document} stems from t1D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 1D}$\end{document} which exponentially increases with EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}.
The minimal search time for a simple TF is tsimple=R3/(3Da)\begin{document}$t_{\rm simple}=R^{3}/(3Da)$\end{document} (Berg, 2018).

For the TF with an IDR, by minimizing the expression in Equation 5, we find that the optimal length approximately scales as L∗∝R\begin{document}$L^{*}\,\propto\,R$\end{document}, and therefore the minimal search time, tmin\begin{document}$t_{\min}$\end{document}, is approximately proportional to R2\begin{document}$R^{2}$\end{document}.

At R=500bp≈1/6μm\begin{document}$R\,=\,500\,\rm bp\,\approx\,1/6\rm\mu m$\end{document}, the search time is more than ten times shorter than a simple TF, despite the latter’s diffusion coefficient being several times larger. Based on our analytic result, we expect ∼50\begin{document}$\sim\,50$\end{document} fold enhancement for the experimental parameters of yeast note that we assume the scaling tmin∼R2\begin{document}$t_{\min}\sim R^{2}$\end{document} still holds in this regime; this formula is approximate since it does not take into account the persistence length of DNA (Guilbaud et al., 2019), which is several-fold shorter than the optimal antenna length L∗\begin{document}$L^{*}$\end{document}. We have verified that reducing the DNA persistence length, which promotes increased DNA coiling, results in only a modest increase in mean search time. Even under extreme coiling conditions, the increase remains below 30% of the baseline value, as detailed in Appendix 9. Robustness of mean total search time with changing the antenna geometry. Converting tmin\begin{document}$t_{\min}$\end{document} into a second-order on-rate yields approximately 108−109M−1s−1\begin{document}$10^{8}-10^{9}\,{\rm M}^{-1}s^{-1}$\end{document}, assuming D≈10−13m2/s\begin{document}$D\approx 10^{-13}m^{2}/s$\end{document} and a TF copy number of 100. We also verified that the 3D diffusion coefficient slightly changes under a complex DNA configuration, where a point-searcher TF non-specifically interacts with the entire DNA, indicating the robustness of our optimal search process (see Appendix 10. MSD in a complex DNA configuration).

Next, we characterize the dynamics of the octopusing walk (Appendix 11. Properties of the octopusing walk). During this process, different IDR binding sites constantly bind and unbind from the antenna, leading to an effective 1D diffusion. A priori, one may think that the TF faces conflicting demands: it has to rapidly diffuse along the DNA while also maintaining strong enough binding to prevent detaching from the DNA too soon. Indeed, within the context of TF search in bacteria, this is known as the speed-stability paradox (Slutsky and Mirny, 2004). Importantly, the simple picture of the octopusing walk explains an elegant mechanism to bypass this paradox, achieving a high diffusion coefficient with a low rate of detaching from the DNA. This comes about due to the compensatory nature of the dynamics: there is, in effect, a feedback mechanism whereby if only a few sites are bound to the DNA, the on-rate increases, and similarly, if too many are bound (thus prohibiting the 1D diffusion) the off-rate increases. Remarkably, this mechanism remains highly effective even when the typical number of binding sites is as low as two. Further details are provided in Appendix 11. Properties of the octopusing walk.

sec.title: Comparing with experimental results
sec.p: In Brodsky et al., 2020, the binding probability of the TF Msn2 in yeast was measured, where the native IDR was shortened by truncating an increasingly large portion of it. The results indicate that binding probability decreases with increasing truncation of the IDR, as illustrated in Figure 4a. We utilized our model to calculate the relative binding probability compared to PTF\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}$\end{document} at a zero truncating length. Using the DBD binding energy EDBD\begin{document}$E_{\rm{DBD}}$\end{document} as our only fitting parameter, our model achieves quantitative agreement with the experimental data. In Figure 4b, we estimate the search time as a function of L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} for R=1μm\begin{document}$R\,=\,1\mu m$\end{document} and D0=10−10m2/s\begin{document}$D_{0}\,=10^{-10}m^{2}/s$\end{document} for a single AA. The estimated timescales are comparable to empirical results, which are 1 to 10 seconds (Kumar et al., 2023; Larson et al., 2011), as indicated by the shaded area. We have also estimated the on-rate kon\begin{document}$k_{\rm on}$\end{document} and off-rate koff\begin{document}$k_{\rm off}$\end{document} of the TF as they vary with IDR length, as shown in Figure 4c. In the kinetic proofreading mechanism (Hopfield, 1974), specificity is associated with the off-rate, but recent studies (Marklund et al., 2022) suggest that in other scenarios, specificity is encoded in the on-rate. Therefore, it is important to explore how specificity is encoded within this mechanism. Our results indicate that the variation in the dissociation constant koff/kon\begin{document}$k_{\rm off}/k_{\rm on}$\end{document} is dominated by koff\begin{document}$k_{\rm off}$\end{document}, suggesting that specificity is encoded in the off-rate. The magnitudes and variations of these rates could be directly compared to experimental results in future studies.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In summary, we addressed the design principles of TFs containing IDRs, with respect to binding affinity and search time. We find that both characteristics are significantly enhanced compared to simple TFs lacking IDRs.

The simplified model we presented provides general design principles for the search process and testable predictions. One possible experiment that could shed light on one of our key assumptions is ‘scrambling’ the DNA (randomizing the order of nucleotides). Our results depend greatly on our assumption that there exists a region on the DNA, close to the DBD target, that contains targets for the IDR binding sites. It is possible to shuffle, or even remove, regions of different lengths around the DBD target and to measure the resulting changes in binding affinity. According to our results, we would expect that shuffling a region smaller in length than the IDR should have minimal effect on the binding affinity and search time, but that shuffling a region longer than the IDR should have a noticeable effect.

Another useful test of our model would be to probe the dynamics of the TF search process by varying the waiting time before TF-DNA interactions are measured: Within the ChEC-seq technique (Zentner et al., 2015) employed in Brodsky et al., 2020, an enzyme capable of cutting the DNA is attached to the TF and activated at will (using an external calcium signal). Sequencing then informs us of the places on the DNA at which the TF was bound at the point of activation. Measuring the binding probabilities at various waiting times — defined as the time between adding calcium ions and adding transcription factors, ranging from seconds to an hour, would inform us both of the TF search dynamics as well as the equilibrium properties: Shorter time scales would capture the dynamics of the search process, while longer time scales would reveal the equilibrium properties of the binding. At short waiting times (within several seconds), we would expect the binding probability to increase with waiting times. By analyzing a normalized binding probability curve as a function of the waiting time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document}, we could fit the curve using the function 1−exp⁡(−t/tsearch)\begin{document}$1\,-\,\exp(-t/t_{\rm search})$\end{document}. From this curve, we can infer the search time. Our results suggest that the presence of the IDR in a TF leads to increased binding probabilities over various waiting times and a reduced waiting time to reach a higher saturation binding probability. Furthermore, as shown in Figure 4 obtained from our model, kon\begin{document}$k_{\rm on}$\end{document} can be determined from the measurements of tsearch\begin{document}$t_{\rm search}$\end{document}. Using the binding probability, which is associated with kD=koff/kon\begin{document}$k_{D}=k_{\rm off}/k_{\rm on}$\end{document}, koff\begin{document}$k_{\rm off}$\end{document} can also be calculated.

While our work primarily focused on coarse-grained modeling of the search process and the hypothesized octopusing dynamics, higher-resolution molecular dynamics simulations could provide more detailed molecular insights and further validate our proposed design principles (Vuzman and Levy, 2010; Vuzman and Levy, 2012). Since these principles are grounded in fundamental physical concepts, such as the energy-entropy trade-off, they are likely to be robust across diverse molecular systems. We anticipate their applicability to other biophysical contexts, such as nonspecific RNA polymerase binding (Tenenbaum et al., 2023) and multivalent antibody binding (Einav et al., 2019), where the associated dynamic processes would also be of significant interest for future research. Beyond our octopusing mechanism, other mechanisms may also contribute to the search and binding process. IDRs could facilitate complex formation and cooperativity between multiple transcription factors, as suggested by studies showing co-localization at common target promoters (Morgunova and Taipale, 2017). IDRs might also enhance efficiency by directing transcription factors to specific nuclear compartments or biomolecular condensates, thereby reducing the effective search space and time (Sabari et al., 2018; Boija et al., 2018; Kent et al., 2020). These complementary mechanisms (Ferrie et al., 2022; Jonas et al., 2025; Holehouse and Kragelund, 2024) suggest that our findings represent one component of a broader regulatory framework governing transcriptional control in eukaryotic cells.

sec.title: Model
sec.p: The Rouse Model describes a polymer as a chain of point masses connected by springs and characterized by a statistical segment length l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} resulting from the rigidity of springs k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} and the thermal noise level kBT\begin{document}$k_{B}T$\end{document}, l02=3kBT/k\begin{document}$l_{0}^{2}=3k_{B}T/k$\end{document} (Prince, 1953; Doi and Edwards, 1988). We coarse-grain the TF by representing it with a few binding sites for the IDR, and an additional site for the DBD, as illustrated in Figure 1b. The targets are assumed to be positioned at equal spacing, with one target for the DBD and a few targets for the IDR, corresponding to the orange and black squares in Figure 1c. We have also verified that relaxing this assumption, and using randomly positioned targets, does not affect our results (Appendix 6. Robustness of the binding design principles). In the Rouse Model, the 3D probability density describing the relative distance in the equilibrium state, denoted as r\begin{document}$r$\end{document}, between any two sites can be derived through Gaussian integration (Doi and Edwards, 1988), leading to:(6)f(r,l)=(32πl2)32exp⁡(−3r22l2),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f(r,l)=\left(\frac{3}{2\pi l^2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\exp{\left(-\frac{3r^{2}}{2l^2}\right)},$$\end{document}
where l=nsegl0\begin{document}$l\,=\,\sqrt{n_{\rm seg}}l_{0}$\end{document} and nseg\begin{document}$n_{\rm seg}$\end{document} is the number of segments between the two sites.

sec.title: Dynamical simulations
sec.p: Each binding site of the TF at position ri\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{r}_{i}$\end{document} follows over-damped dynamics, which reads:(7)Δri=DkBTf({ri})Δt+2DΔtξ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta\boldsymbol{r}_{i}=\frac{D}{k_{B}T}\boldsymbol{f}(\left\{\boldsymbol{r}_{i}\right\})\Delta t+\sqrt{2D\Delta t}\,\boldsymbol{\xi},$$\end{document}

where the random variable ξ\begin{document}$\xi$\end{document} follows the standard normal distribution. D\begin{document}$D$\end{document} is the diffusion coefficient of the coarse-grained binding site. The force acting on each site is f({ri})≡−∂Utotal/∂ri\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{f}(\left\{\boldsymbol{r}_{i}\right\})\equiv-\partial U_{{\rm total}}/\partial\boldsymbol{r }_{i}$\end{document}, and(8)Utotal=∑i=0nb−112k(ri+1−ri)2+∑i,jEBexp⁡[−(ri−Rj)22wd2],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle U_{\rm total}=\sum\limits_{i=0}^{n_b-1}{\frac{1}{2}k(\boldsymbol{r}_{i+1}-\boldsymbol{r}_{i})^{2}}+ \sum\limits_{i,j}{E_B\exp{\left[-\frac{\left(\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{R}_{j}\right)^{2}}{2 w_{d}^{2}}\right]}},$$\end{document}

where Rj\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{R}_{j}$\end{document} are the positions of the targets. wd=1bp\begin{document}$w_{d}\,=\,1\rm bp$\end{document} is the typical width of the short-range interaction between sites and their corresponding targets. The typical distance l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} between coarse-grained binding sites is 5bp\begin{document}$5\rm bp$\end{document}. The stiffness of the springs is thus 3kBT/l02=3kBT/25bp2\begin{document}$3k_{B}T/l_{0}^{2}=3k_{B}T/25\rm bp^{2}$\end{document}. To speed up the simulations, when the sites’ minimal distance to the antenna is larger than the threshold 10bp\begin{document}$10\rm bp$\end{document}, the TF is regarded as a rigid body, and all sites move in sync with their center of mass. We verified that the resulting search time is insensitive to the value of this threshold. When the sites’ minimal distance to the antenna is less than 10bp\begin{document}$10\rm bp$\end{document}, we consider the excluded volume effect to ensure that different binding sites are not trapped at the same target. Specifically, we use the WCA interaction (Weeks et al., 1971):(9)UWCA={σ12|ri−rj|12−2σ6|ri−rj|6+1,|ri−rj|<σ0,|ri−rj|≥σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle U_{{\rm WCA}}=\begin{cases} \frac{\sigma^{12}}{\left|\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{r}_{j}\right|^{12}}-\frac{2\sigma^{6}}{\left|\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{r}_{j}\right|^{6}}+1, & \left|\boldsymbol{r}_{i}\,-\,\boldsymbol{r}_{j}\right| \lt \sigma\\ 0, & \left|\boldsymbol{r}_{i}\,-\,\boldsymbol{r}_{j}\right|\geq\sigma \end{cases} $$\end{document}

where σ=1bp\begin{document}$\sigma=1\rm bp$\end{document}. In this region, we also adopted an adaptive time step: Δt/(bp2/D)=min{1,kBTmax|fi|bp}×0.01\begin{document}$\Delta t/({\rm bp^{2}}/D)=\min\left\{1,\,\frac{k_{B}T}{\max|\boldsymbol{f}_{i}|\,{\rm bp }}\right\}\times 0.01$\end{document}. Note that this choice ensures that the displacement of the sites at every step is much smaller than the binding site size wd\begin{document}$w_{d}$\end{document}. Due to the IDR trapped in the binding targets on the antenna, which results in slow dynamics, the simulation time becomes significantly longer, as found in previous simulation studies (Vuzman and Levy, 2010; Marcovitz and Levy, 2013). This slowdown is similar to the behavior observed in glass-forming liquids (Berthier and Biroli, 2011). As a result, the individual simulation time steps range from 109 to 1011.

sec.title: Broad applicability of probability density f(r,l)\begin{document}$f(r,l)$\end{document}
sec.p: We verify the broad applicability of Equation 6 in the main text, regardless of the specific details of microscopic interactions. To demonstrate this, we only require that the density function of the end-to-end distance r\begin{document}$r$\end{document} for a segment containing m\begin{document}$m$\end{document} amino acids (AAs), denoted as f(r,l0)\begin{document}$f(r,l_{0})$\end{document}, complies with Equation 6. Specifically, it is.(10)f(r,l0)≈(32πl02)3/2exp⁡(−3r22l02),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f(r,l_0)\approx \left(\frac{3}{2\pi l_0^2} \right)^{3/2}\exp{\left(-\frac{3r^{2}}{2l_0^2}\right)},$$\end{document}

where l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} is the typical length of the segment. When m\begin{document}$m$\end{document} is large, according to the central limit theorem, r\begin{document}$r$\end{document} should conform to the distribution in Equation 10 with a variance of l02=maeff2\begin{document}$l_{0}^{2}=ma_{\rm eff}^{2}$\end{document}, where aeff\begin{document}$a_{\rm eff}$\end{document} represents the effective length of an individual AA.

Next, we will consider a specific form of interaction, of springs with a finite rest length. In one limit (where the rest length vanishes), this corresponds to the Rouse model (where Equation 10 is exact for any value of m\begin{document}$m$\end{document}, not only asymptotically) and in another limit (where the springs are very stiff) this corresponds to a chain of rods. As we shall see, Equation 10 provides an excellent approximation already for moderate values of m\begin{document}$m$\end{document}.

To proceed, we consider two adjacent AAs at positions r→i\begin{document}$\vec{r}_{i}$\end{document} and r→i+1\begin{document}$\vec{r}_{i+1}$\end{document} with an interaction denoted by u(|r→i−r→i+1|)\begin{document}$u(|\vec{r}_{i}\,-\,\vec{r}_{i+1}|)$\end{document}. Their probability density is ρ(r→i,r→i+1)∝exp⁡(−u(|r→i−r→i+1|)/(kBT))\begin{document}$\rho(\vec{r}_{i},\vec{r}_{i+1})\propto\exp\left(-u(|\vec{r}_{i}\,-\,\vec{r}_{i +1}|)/(k_{B}T)\right)$\end{document}. aeff2\begin{document}$a_{\rm eff}^{2}$\end{document} can be calculated using ρ(r→i,r→i+1)\begin{document}$\rho(\vec{r}_{i},\vec{r}_{i+1})$\end{document}:(11)aeff2=∫dr→∫dr→i∫dr→i+1|r→i−r→i+1|2ρ(r→i,r→i+1)δ(r→−(r→i−r→i+1)).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle a_{\rm eff}^{2} =\int d\vec{r}\int d\vec{r}_{i}\int d\vec{r}_{i+1}\,|\vec{r}_{i}\,-\,\vec{r}_{i+1}|^{2}\rho(\vec{r}_{i},\vec{r}_{i+1})\delta\left(\vec{r}\,-\,\left(\vec{r}_{i}\,-\,\vec{r}_{i+1}\right)\right). $$\end{document}

Specifically, for a spring-like interaction with a stiffness constant k0\begin{document}$k_{0}$\end{document} and a rest length b0\begin{document}$b_{0}$\end{document}, the interaction is given by u=12k0(|r→i−r→i+1|−b0)2\begin{document}$u=\frac{1}{2}k_{0}\left(|\vec{r}_{i}\,-\,\vec{r}_{i+1}|\,-\,b_{0}\right)^{2}$\end{document}. This formula can also be interpreted as a harmonic approximation of the interaction around the equilibrium distance b0\begin{document}$b_{0}$\end{document}. In this case, aeff2\begin{document}$a_{\rm eff}^{2}$\end{document} is derived analytically:(12)aeff2=a02+b02+2b02a02a02+3b02(1+2a036b02a0+6πb0(a02+3b02)(1+{\rm Erf}(32b0a0))exp⁡(3b022a02)),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle a_{\rm eff}^{2} =a_{0}^{2}\,+\,b_{0}^{2}\,+\,\frac{2b_{0}^{2}a_{0}^{2}}{a_{0}^{2}+3b_{0}^{2}}(1\,+\,\frac{2a_{0}^{3}}{6b_{0}^{2}a_{0}\,+\,\sqrt{6\pi}b_{0}\left(a_{0}^{2}+3b_{0}^{2}\right)\left(1+\text{{\rm Erf}}(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}\frac{b_{0}}{a_{0}})\right)\exp(\frac{3b_{0}^{2}}{2a_{0}^{2}})}),$$\end{document}

where a02≡3k0/kBT\begin{document}$a_{0}^{2}\,\equiv\,3k_{0}/k_{B}T$\end{document} and Erf(z)=2π∫0zexp⁡(−x2/2)dx\begin{document}${\rm Erf}(z)\,=\,\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\int_{0}^{z}\exp(-x^{2}/2)dx$\end{document} is the error function. When b0=0\begin{document}$b_{0}\,=\,0$\end{document}, we have aeff=a0\begin{document}$a_{\rm eff}\,=\,a_{0}$\end{document}, and Equation 10holds for any m\begin{document}$m$\end{document}. When b0≫a0\begin{document}$b_{0}\,\gg\,a_{0}$\end{document}, then aeff≈b0\begin{document}$a_{\rm eff}\,\approx\,b_{0}$\end{document} corresponds to a chain of rods where the angle between consecutive rods is free to rotate.

Appendix 1—figure 1a shows that the numerical results obtained from this harmonic interaction are in good agreement with Equation 10 even at moderate values of m\begin{document}$m$\end{document}. The inset displays the variation of aeff2/a02\begin{document}$a_{\rm eff}^{2}/a_{0}^{2}$\end{document} with b0/a0\begin{document}$b_{0}/a_{0}$\end{document} obtained from Equation 12. In Appendix 1—figure 1b, with b0=a0\begin{document}$b_{0}\,=\,a_{0}$\end{document}, f(r,l0)\begin{document}$f(r,l_{0})$\end{document} rapidly converges to Equation 10.

sec.title: Derivation of the binding probability
sec.p: In this section, we derive the generalized binding probability PTF\begin{document}$P_{{\rm TF}}$\end{document} for nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} IDR binding sites and nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document} IDR targets. To achieve this generalization, we consider all the possible number of bindings, n\begin{document}$n$\end{document} from 0 to min(nb,nt)\begin{document}$\min(n_{b},n_{t})$\end{document}, and all possibilities for binding orientations for each n\begin{document}$n$\end{document}. Note that the energy and entropy trade-off is naturally included in our model, and the generalized formula of PTF\begin{document}$P_{{\rm TF}}$\end{document} is also applicable for non-uniformly distributed binding targets and binding sites.

Based on the Rouse model, the system’s energy can be expressed as k2∑i=1nb(r→i−r→i−1)2=3kBT2l02∑i=1nb(r→i−r→i−1)2\begin{document}$\frac{k}{2}\sum_{i\,=\,1}^{n_{b}}(\vec{r}_{i}-\vec{r}_{i\,-\,1})^{2}=\frac{3k_ {B}T}{2l_{0}^{2}}\sum_{i\,=\,1}^{n_{b}}(\vec{r}_{i}-\vec{r}_{i\,-\,1})^{2}$\end{document}, where r→i\begin{document}$\vec{r}_{i}$\end{document} represents the position of the binding site i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}. The probability density in the absence of binding reads:(13)ρ(r→0,...,r→nb)=1Vc(32πl02)32nbe−32l02∑i=1nb(r→i−r→i−1)2,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \rho(\vec{r}_{0},...,\vec{r}_{n_{b}})\, =\frac{1}{V_{c}}\left(\frac{3}{2\pi l_{0}^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}n_{b}}e^{-\frac{3}{2l_{0}^{2}}\sum_{i\,=\,1}^{n_{b}}(\vec{r}_{i}-\vec{r}_{i\,-\,1})^{2}},$$\end{document}
where ∫d3r→0...∫d3r→nbρ(r→0,...,r→nb)=1\begin{document}$\int\,d^{3}\vec{r}_{0}...\int\,d^{3}\vec{r}_{n_{b}}\rho(\vec{r}_{0},...,\vec{r }_{n_{b}})\,=\,1$\end{document}.

Now we consider a given configuration with n\begin{document}$n$\end{document} IDR sites bound, where IDR sites q1<...<qn\begin{document}$q_{1}\,\lt \,...\,\lt \,q_{n}$\end{document} are bound to targets s1,...,sn.\begin{document}$s_{1},...,s_{n}.$\end{document} The positions of these bound targets are at R→s1,...,R→sn\begin{document}$\vec{R}_{s_{1}},...,\vec{R}_{s_{n}}$\end{document}. The DBD site is denoted by q0=0\begin{document}$q_{0}\,=\,0$\end{document} and its target is denoted by s0=0\begin{document}$s_{0}\,=\,0$\end{document}. There are nb−n\begin{document}$n_{b}\,-\,n$\end{document} unbound IDR sites, indicated by q¯1<...<q¯nb−n\begin{document}$\bar{q}_{1}\,\lt \,...\,\lt \bar{q}_{n_{b}\,-\,n}$\end{document}. The corresponding binding probability is given by:(14)Pbound(orn,n)=1Z∏i=0n∫r→qi∈V1d3r→qi∏ℓ=1nb−n∫r→q¯ℓ∉V1d3r→q¯ℓρ(r→0,…,r→nb)eEDBD+nEB\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{\text{bound}}(\text{orn},n) \;=\; \frac{1}{Z} \prod_{i=0}^{n} \int_{\vec{r}_{q_{i}} \in V_{1}} d^{3}\vec{r}_{q_{i}} \prod_{\ell=1}^{n_{b}-n} \int_{\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}} \notin V_{1}} d^{3}\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}} \, \rho(\vec{r}_{0}, \ldots, \vec{r}_{n_{b}}) \, e^{E_{\text{DBD}} + nE_{B}}$$\end{document}

where ‘orn\begin{document}$\rm orn$\end{document}’ stands for the orientation of the given configuration, Z\begin{document}$Z$\end{document} is the normalization factor, and EDBD\begin{document}$E_{\rm DBD}$\end{document} is the DBD site binding energy for its target. There are (nbn)(ntn)n!\begin{document}${n_{b}\choose n}{n_{t}\choose n}n!$\end{document} possible binding orientations at n\begin{document}$n$\end{document}. The key insight in evaluating this integral is to realize that we can use the result of Equation 6 of the main text to integrate out the degrees of freedom associated with the sites between qi−1\begin{document}$q_{i\,-\,1}$\end{document} and qi\begin{document}$q_{i}$\end{document}:(15)∏q¯ℓ=qi−1+1qi−1[∫d3r→q¯ℓ(32πl02)3/2exp⁡(−3(r→q¯ℓ−r→q¯ℓ−1)22l02)]=f(|r→qi−r→qi−1|,qi−qi−1l0).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \prod\limits_{\bar{q}_{\ell}=q_{i-1}\,+\,1}^{q_{i}-1}{\left[\int\,d^{3}\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}}\left(\frac{3}{2\pi l_{0}^{2}}\right)^{3/2}\exp\left(-\frac{3(\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}}\,-\,\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}\,-\,1})^{2}}{2l_{0}^{2}}\right)\right] =f\left(\left|\vec{r}_{q_{i}}\,-\,\vec{r}_{q_{i\,-\,1}\,}\right|,\sqrt{q_{i}\,-\,q_{i\,-\,1}}l_{0}\right)}.$$\end{document}

Since rqi−1\begin{document}$r_{q_{i\,-\,1}}$\end{document} and rqi\begin{document}$r_{q_{i}}$\end{document} are confined to a very small volume V1\begin{document}$V_{1}$\end{document}, to an excellent approximation we may simply evaluate f(|r→qi−r→qi−1|,qi−qi−1l0)\begin{document}$f\left(\left|\vec{r}_{q_{i}}\,-\,\vec{r}_{q_{i\,-\,1}\,}\right|,\sqrt{q_{i}\,- \,q_{i\,-\,1}}l_{0}\right)$\end{document} in Equation 15 at r→qi−1=R→si−1\begin{document}$\vec{r}_{q_{i\,-\,1}}\,=\,\vec{R}_{s_{i\,-\,1}}$\end{document} and r→qi=R→si\begin{document}$\vec{r}_{q_{i}}\,=\,\vec{R}_{s_{i}}$\end{document}, to obtain:(16)Pbound(orn,n)≃1ZV1n+1Vc∏i=1nf(|si−si−1|d,qi−qi−1l0)eEDBD+nEB=1ZrDBD∏i=1nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{{\rm bound}\,}({\rm orn},n) \simeq\frac{1}{Z}\frac{V_{1}^{n+1}}{V_{c}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}f(\left|s_{i}\,-\,s_{i\,-\,1}\right|d,\sqrt{q_{i}\,-\,q_{i\,-\,1}}l_{0})e^{E_{{\rm DBD}}+nE_{B}}\,=\,\frac{1}{Z}r_{{\rm DBD}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i}),$$\end{document}

where rDBD≡V1VceEDBD\begin{document}$r_{\rm DBD}\equiv \frac{V_1}{V_c}e^{E_{DBD}} $\end{document}, rorn,i=|si−si−1|d\begin{document}$r_{{\rm orn}, i}=\left|s_i-s_{i-1}\right|d $\end{document}, lorn,i=qi−qi−1l0\begin{document}$l_{{\rm orn},i}=\sqrt{q_i-q_{i-1}}l_0 $\end{document}, and P(EB,rorn,i)=eEBV1f(rorn,i,lorn,i)\begin{document}$\mathcal{P}\left(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i}\right)=e^{E_B}V_1f\left(r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i}\right) $\end{document}.

To give a specific example, consider the binding topology corresponding to Appendix 2—figure 1. In this case, n=3\begin{document}$n\,=\,3$\end{document}, lorn,1=l0\begin{document}$l_{\rm orn,1}\,=\,l_{0}$\end{document} (since there is one spring between the DBD and the first binding site), lorn,2=3l0\begin{document}$l_{\rm orn,2}\,=\,\sqrt{3}l_{0}$\end{document} (since there are three springs between q1\begin{document}$q_{1}$\end{document} and q2\begin{document}$q_{2}$\end{document}) and similarly lorn,3=l0\begin{document}$l_{\rm orn,3}=\,l_{0}$\end{document}. Equation 15 implies that the contribution of this diagram to the binding probability is: 1ZV14Vc27(2πl02)9/2e3EB+EDBD−5d2/l02\begin{document}$\frac{1}{Z}\frac{\text{$V_{1}^{4}$}}{V_{c}}\frac{27}{\left(2\pi l_{0}^{2} \right)^{9/2}}e^{3E_{B}+E_{{\rm DBD}}-5d^{2}/l_{0}^{2}}$\end{document}. Note that while in this example, the order of the target sites is monotonic (i.e. as we increase the index of the binding sites, we progressively move further away from the DBD), in principle, we should sum over all diagrams, including those where the order is non-monotonic. At n=0\begin{document}$n=0$\end{document}, Pbound(orn,0)=1ZrDBD\begin{document}$P_{{\rm bound}\,}({\rm orn},0)=\frac{1}{Z}r_{{\rm DBD}}$\end{document}.

sec.p: Similarly, for the state where the DBD is unbound and n≥2\begin{document}$n\geq 2$\end{document} IDR sites are bound, the binding probability reads:(17)Punbound(orn,n)=1Z∫r→0∉V1d3r→0∏ℓ=1n∫r→qℓ∈V1d3r→qℓ∏ℓ=1nb−n∫r→q¯ℓ∉V1d3r→q¯ℓρ(r→0,...,r→nb)enEB\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{{\rm unbound}\,}({\rm orn},n) =&\frac{1}{Z}\int_{\vec{r}_{0}\,\notin\,V_{1}}\,d^{3}\vec{r}_{0}\prod_{\ell=1}^{n}\int_{\vec{r}_{q_{\ell}}\,\in\,V_{1}}d^{3}\vec{r}_{q_{\ell}}\prod_{\ell=1}^{n_{b}-n}\,\int_{\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}}\,\notin\,V_{1}}d^{3}\vec{r}_{\bar{q}_{\ell}}\rho(\vec{r}_{0},...,\vec{r}_{n_{b}})e^{nE_{B}}$$\end{document}(18)≃1ZrIDR∏i=2nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \simeq & \frac{1}{Z}r_{{\rm IDR}}\prod_{i=2}^{n} \mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i}),$$\end{document}

where rIDR≡V1VceEB\begin{document}$r_{{\rm IDR}}\,\equiv\,\frac{V_{1}}{V_{c}}e^{E_{B}}$\end{document}. For n=1\begin{document}$n\,=\,1$\end{document}, Punbound(orn,1)=ntnbZrIDR\begin{document}$P_{{\rm unbound}\,}({\rm orn},1)=\frac{n_{t}n_{b}}{Z}r_{{\rm IDR}}$\end{document}. Here ntnb\begin{document}$n_{t}n_{b}$\end{document} represents the number of possibilities for one of the nb\begin{document}$n_{b}$\end{document} IDR sites bound to one of the nt\begin{document}$n_{t}$\end{document} targets. For n=0\begin{document}$n\,=\,0$\end{document}, Punbound(orn,0)=1Z∏i=0nb∫r→i∉V1d3r→iρ(r→0,...,r→nb)≃1Z\begin{document}$P_{{\rm unbound}\,}({\rm orn},0)=\frac{1}{Z}\prod_{i=0}^{n_{b}}\int_{\vec{r}_{ i}\notin V_{1}}d^{3}\vec{r}_{i}\rho(\vec{r}_{0},...,\vec{r}_{n_{b}})\simeq \frac{1}{Z}$\end{document}.

Since the sum of all the possibilities is equal to 1, as given by: ∑n=0nmin∑orn(Pbound+Punbound)=1\begin{document}$\sum_{n=0}^{n_{\min}}\,\sum_{{\rm orn}}\left(P_{{\rm bound}}\,+\,P_{{\rm unbound }}\right)\,=\,1$\end{document}, where nmin=min{nb,nt}\begin{document}$n_{\min}\,=\,\min\{n_{b},n_{t}\}$\end{document}, we can determine the normalization factor. Therefore, the binding probability PTF\begin{document}$P_{{\rm TF}}$\end{document} for the DBD bound in its target can be expressed as:(19)PTF=rDBD(1+∑n=1nmin∑orn∏i=1nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i))rDBD(1+∑n=1nmin∑orn∏i=1nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i))+1+rIDR(ntnb+∑n=2nmin∑orn∏i=2nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i)).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{{\rm TF}}=\frac{r_{{\rm DBD}}\left(1\,+\,\sum\limits _{n=1}^{n_{\min}}\sum\limits _{{\rm orn}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i})\right)}{r_{{\rm DBD}}\left(1\,+\,\sum\limits _{n=1}^{n_{\min}}\sum\limits _{{\rm orn}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i})\right)\,+\,1\,+r_{{\rm IDR}}\left(n_tn_{b}\,+\,\sum\limits _{n=2}^{n_{\min}}\sum\limits _{{\rm orn}}\prod_{i=2}^{n}\mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i})\right)}.$$\end{document}

When PTF≪1\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}\,\ll\,1$\end{document}, we can approximate PTF\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}$\end{document} as(20)PTF≈(1+∑n=1nmin∑orn∏i=1nP(EB,rorn,i,lorn,i))Psimple,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{{\rm TF}}\approx \left(1\,+\,\sum\limits _{n=1}^{n_{\min}}\sum\limits _{{\rm orn}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{P}(E_B,r_{{\rm orn},i},l_{{\rm orn},i})\right)P_{\rm simple},$$\end{document}

where we have considered the facts that rIDR<rDBD\begin{document}$r_{\rm IDR}\,\lt \,r_{\rm DBD}$\end{document} because EB<EDBD\begin{document}$E_{B}\,\lt \,E_{\rm DBD}$\end{document}, and Psimple=rDBD/(1+rDBD)≈rDBD\begin{document}$P_{\rm{simple}}\,=\,r_{\rm DBD}/(1+r_{\rm DBD})\,\approx\,r_{\rm DBD}$\end{document} due to rDBD≪1\begin{document}$r_{\rm DBD}\,\ll 1$\end{document}. For instance, taking EDBD=15\begin{document}$E_{\rm DBD}\,=\,15$\end{document}, V1=1bp3≈(0.34nm)3\begin{document}$V_{1}\,=\,1\rm{bp}^{3}\approx(0.34nm)^{3}$\end{document}, and Vc=1μm3\begin{document}$V_{c}\,=\,1\mu m^{3}$\end{document}, we find that rDBD∼10−4\begin{document}$r_{\rm DBD}\,\sim\,10^{-4}$\end{document}.

At nb=nt=1\begin{document}$n_{b}\,=\,n_{t}=\,1$\end{document}, the generalized Equation 19 simplifies to the following expression:(21)PTF=rDBD[1+eEBV1f(d,l0)]rDBD[1+eEBV1f(d,l0)]+rIDR+1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_{{\rm TF}}=\frac{r_{\rm DBD}\left[1+e^{E_{B}}V_1f(d,l_{0})\right]}{r_{{\rm DBD}}\left[1+e^{ E_{B}}V_1f(d,l_{0})\right]+r_{{\rm IDR}}+1}.$$\end{document}

Therefore, PTF\begin{document}$P_{\rm TF}$\end{document} can be approximated as (1+P)Psimple\begin{document}$(1+\mathcal{P})P_{\rm{simple}}$\end{document}, as illustrated in Equation 1 of the main text. This approximation is also derivable from Equation 20.

Here, we also explore the scenario where both IDR binding sites and their targets are distributed as a Poisson process (i.e. the distance between neighboring sites is exponentially distributed), with mean values of l0\begin{document}$l_{0}$\end{document} and d\begin{document}$d$\end{document}, respectively. sec.title: TF walking along the antenna once it attaches, and ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} vs. EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} and vs. n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document}
sec.p: We show a typical example of the trajectory of a TF (red) in the cell nucleus (light blue) in Appendix 7—figure 1a where the TF walks along the antenna to the DBD target once it attaches the IDR targets at n~∗\begin{document}$\tilde{n}^{*}$\end{document} and EB∗\begin{document}$E_{B}^{*}$\end{document}. The DBD target is at the origin. In Appendix 7—figure 1b, we find that the average number of rounds the TF hits the antenna, nhits\begin{document}$n_{\rm hits}$\end{document}, is close to 1, so it is fair to describe the overall search process as two distinct steps with the first step being purely a 3D search and the second a purely 1D search. sec.title: A single round of 3D-1D search is typically the case in the optimal search process
sec.p: In this section, we will show that the optimal search process (i.e. minimizing the mean first passage time) generically takes place via a single round of 3D-1D search. To do so, we first need to derive the expression for the mean total search time, ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document}, and its dependence on the relevant parameters, including, importantly, EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document} and L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}. According to our model presented in the main text: A TF is initially in the 3D nucleus space; it can attach to the antenna and perform 1D diffusion with the coefficient denoted by D1\begin{document}$D_{1}$\end{document}. We assume the DBD target is placed in the middle of the antenna, as shown in Figure 1 of the main text. The mean search time taken for a TF to move from 3D space and attach to the antenna is denoted by t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document}. The TF can also detach from the antenna at a rate we denote by Γ\begin{document}$\Gamma$\end{document}, perform a 3D random walk, until ultimately attaching again to the antenna. In the following, we will make the assumption (often made in the context of FD model Berg et al., 1981; Berg and von Hippel, 1987; Slutsky and Mirny, 2004; Mirny et al., 2009; Li et al., 2009; Bénichou et al., 2011; Sheinman et al., 2012) that the binding position after such a 3D excursion is uniformly distributed on the antenna.

Both D1\begin{document}$D_{1}$\end{document} and Γ\begin{document}$\Gamma$\end{document} are functions of EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}. When the TF is on the antenna, its mean search time to reach the DBD target, located a distance x\begin{document}$x$\end{document} away on the antenna, is represented by T(x)\begin{document}$\mathcal{T}(x)$\end{document}. Naturally, T(x)\begin{document}$\mathcal{T}(x)$\end{document} is zero when x=0\begin{document}$x=0$\end{document}, the location of the DBD target. The mean total search time ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} is thus given by(22)ttotal=1L∫−L/2L/2T(x)dx+t3D.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle t_{{\rm total}} =\frac{1}{L}\int_{-L/2}^{L/2}\mathcal{T}(x)dx+t_{{\rm 3D}}.$$\end{document}

Consider a time interval Δt\begin{document}$\Delta t$\end{document}. With probability ΓΔt\begin{document}$\Gamma\,\Delta t$\end{document} the TF falls off, and the mean first passage time to reach the target is ttotal+Δt\begin{document}$t_{{\rm total}}+\Delta t$\end{document}. Otherwise, with probability 1−ΓΔt\begin{document}$1-\Gamma\,\Delta t$\end{document}, the mean first passage time would be the average of the two possible outcomes, namely, (T(x+Δx)+T(x−Δx))/2+Δt\begin{document}$(\mathcal{T}(x\,+\,\Delta x)+\mathcal{T}(x\,-\,\Delta x))/2+\Delta t$\end{document}. This recursive reasoning leads us to the following equation:(23)T(x)=Δt+T(x−Δx)+T(x+Δx)2(1−ΓΔt)+ttotalΓΔt.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal{T}(x) =\Delta t+\frac{\mathcal{T}(x - \Delta x)+\mathcal{T}(x + \Delta x)}{2}\left(1-\Gamma \Delta t\right)+t_{{\rm total}}\Gamma \Delta t.$$\end{document}

In the continuous limit, we have(24)D1∂2T(x)∂x2−ΓT(x)+Γttotal+1=0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{1}\frac{\partial^{2}\mathcal{T}(x)}{\partial x^{2}}-\Gamma\mathcal{T}(x)+\Gamma t_{{\rm total}}+1 =0,$$\end{document}

where D1≡(Δx)2/(2Δt)\begin{document}$D_{1}\equiv(\Delta x)^{2}/(2\Delta t)$\end{document}. By applying the boundary conditions, specifically the absorbing boundary condition at x=0\begin{document}$x=0$\end{document} and the reflecting boundary conditions at x=±L/2\begin{document}$x=\pm L/2$\end{document}, T(x)\begin{document}$\mathcal{T}(x)$\end{document} is determined as(25)T(x)=(ttotal+Γ−1)[1−cosh⁡(L−2|x|Ls)cosh⁡(LLs)],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal{T}(x) =\left(t_{{\rm total}}+\Gamma^{-1}\right)\left[1-\frac{\cosh(\frac{L-2|x|}{L_{s}})}{\cosh(\frac{L}{L_{s}})}\right],$$\end{document}

where Ls\begin{document}$L_{s}$\end{document}, representing the 1D diffusion distance, is defined by Ls≡2D1Γ−1\begin{document}$L_{s}\,\equiv\,2\sqrt{D_{1}\Gamma^{-1}}$\end{document}(Wunderlich and Mirny, 2008). Therefore, ttotal\begin{document}$t_{{\rm total}}$\end{document} can be self-consistently solved by substituting T(x)\begin{document}$\mathcal{T}(x)$\end{document} into Equation 22, presented as follows:(26)ttotal=LLscoth⁡(LLs)t3D+[LLscoth⁡(LLs)−1]Γ−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle t_{{\rm total}} =\frac{L}{L_{s}}{\coth\left(\frac{L}{L_{s}}\right)}t_{{\rm 3D}}+\left[\frac{L}{L_{s}}{\coth\left(\frac{L}{L_{s}}\right)}-1\right]\Gamma^{-1}.$$\end{document}
We can obtain ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} in two limiting cases:

list-item.p: When L≫Ls\begin{document}$L\gg L_{s}$\end{document}, where multiple rounds of 3D-1D excursions are needed to find the target, we have ttotal=LLs(t3D+Γ−1)\begin{document}$t_{{\rm total}}=\frac{L}{L_{s}}\left(t_{{\rm 3D}}+\Gamma^{-1}\right)$\end{document}. This is the same as the results of the facilitated diffusion model (Wunderlich and Mirny, 2008; Bénichou et al., 2011; Sheinman et al., 2012; Hachmo and Amir, 2023).

When L≪Ls\begin{document}$L\ll L_{s}$\end{document}, where a single round of 3D-1D search can find the target, we get ttotal=t3D+L212D1\begin{document}$t_{{\rm total}}=t_{{\rm 3D}}+\frac{L^{2}}{12D_{1}}$\end{document}. This matches Equation 5 in the main text when L<2R\begin{document}$L \lt 2R$\end{document}.

sec.p: Note that the calculations above did not assume an optimal or efficient search process, but simply characterized the dependence of the mean first passage time on the model parameters. Next, based on the expression for ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} in Equation 26, we will prove that the search process involving multiple rounds of 3D-1D search is not optimal. This conclusion is reached by showing that the minimum ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} always occurs in the regime where L<2Ls\begin{document}$L\,\lt \,2L_{s}$\end{document} (since Ls\begin{document}$L_{s}$\end{document} is the typical distance covered by 1D diffusion on the antenna before falling off, and the maximal distance needed to be traversed on the antenna is L/2\begin{document}$L/2$\end{document}). We emphasize an important distinction between our model and the well-studied facilitated diffusion model (where it is established that multiple rounds of search are needed for efficient search): in our case, the antenna length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} is a variable that can be optimized over (since we assume evolution has optimized over the size of the region flanking the DBD in which binding sites for the IDR are located). In the facilitated diffusion model, L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} is assumed to be the length of the genome, since the interactions of the TF and the DNA are assumed non-specific. To proceed, let us first note that the factor coth⁡(LLs)\begin{document}$\coth\left(\frac{L}{L_{s}}\right)$\end{document} in Equation 26 quickly converges to 1 as the ratio of L/Ls\begin{document}$L/L_{s}$\end{document} increases. For instance, when the ratio is 2, we have coth⁡(2)≈1.04\begin{document}$\coth(2)\,\approx\,1.04$\end{document}. Thus, for L>2Ls\begin{document}$L\,\gt \,2L_{s}$\end{document}, we could approximate ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} as(27)ttotal≈LLst3D+(LLs−1)Γ−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle t_{\rm total}\,\approx \,\frac{L}{L_{s}}t_{{\rm 3D}} \,+\,\left(\frac{L}{L_{s}}-1\right)\Gamma^{-1}.$$\end{document}

Then, we consider how t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document} varies with L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}. If the rate to hit the antenna after 3D diffusion was the sum of the rates to hit every infinitesimal segment of it, we would expect the rate to hit the antenna to be linear in L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}, and the mean first passage time to scale as 1/L\begin{document}$1/L$\end{document}. However, these processes are not uncorrelated. Interestingly, when L<2R\begin{document}$L\,\lt \,2R$\end{document}, and assuming a straight antenna, t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document} is proportional to ln⁡(L)/L\begin{document}$\ln(L)/L$\end{document} (see Equation 5 in the main text), implying that for a straight antenna the effect of these correlations is mild. However, when L>2R\begin{document}$L\,\gt \,2R$\end{document}, the antenna is curved rather than straight (due to the limitations imposed on the DNA conformation by the dimensions of the nucleus), and the dependence of t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document} on L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} is weaker (Hu et al., 2006). Thus, for any given L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} greater than 2Ls\begin{document}$2L_{s}$\end{document}, t3D\begin{document}$t_{\rm 3D}$\end{document} varies more weakly than 1/L\begin{document}$1/L$\end{document}, making the first term of ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} in Equation 27 an increasing function of L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}. Clearly, the second term increases as well. Therefore, when L>2Ls\begin{document}$L\,\gt \,2L_{s}$\end{document}, regardless of the functional forms of D1\begin{document}$D_{1}$\end{document} and Γ−1\begin{document}$\Gamma^{-1}$\end{document} on EB\begin{document}$E_{B}$\end{document}, ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} decreases with decreasing L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}. Thus, the minimum ttotal\begin{document}$t_{\rm total}$\end{document} occurs in the regime where L<2Ls\begin{document}$L\,\lt \,2L_{s}$\end{document}, and the optimal search typically consists of a single search round.

sec.title: Robustness of mean total search time with changing the antenna geometry
sec.p: We checked that the mean total search time (Mean First Passage Time) for IDR targets, generated via the worm-like chain model – a random walk with a persistence length (Milstein and Meiners, 2013), does not significantly differ from the scenario where targets are arranged linearly, as presented in the main text. See Appendix 9—figure 1 for details.

The mean total search times do not exhibit significant differences compared to that for targets arranged linearly (indicated by the horizontal orange line).

sec.title: MSD in a complex DNA configuration
sec.p: In Appendix 10—figure 1, we run simulations to examine how the Mean Square Displacement (MSD) of a point searcher is influenced by the binding energy (Enonsp\begin{document}$E_{\rm nonsp}$\end{document}) between the TF and the entire DNA in a complex DNA configuration. Appendix 10—figure 1a shows the DNA configuration generated via the worm-like chain model with a persistence length of 150 bp (Milstein and Meiners, 2013), where the volume fraction ν=0.008\begin{document}$\nu\,=\,0.008$\end{document} is comparable to the experimental yeast DNA volume fraction. Appendix 10—figure 1b shows the MSD measured at different values of Enonsp\begin{document}$E_{\rm nonsp}$\end{document} for ν=0.008\begin{document}$\nu=0.008$\end{document}. When Enonsp∼1kBT\begin{document}$E_{\rm nonsp}\sim 1k_{B}T$\end{document}, which corresponds to the non-specific binding energy regime in experiments (Afek et al., 2014), the effective 3D diffusion coefficient is slightly modified, which does not affect our conclusion on the optimal search process. Additionally, we observed that the MSD curve bends when Enonsp\begin{document}$E_{\rm nonsp}$\end{document} exceeds the typical range of non-specific binding energies.

It detaches at a rate of D31nm2exp⁡(−Enonsp/kBT)\begin{document}$\frac{D_{3}}{1nm^{2}}\exp(-E_{\rm nonsp}/k_{B}T)$\end{document}. (b) MSD at different Enonsp\begin{document}$E_{\rm nonsp}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Properties of the octopusing walk
sec.p: Once an IDR site binds to the antenna, the TF performs an octopusing walk, whereby different IDR binding sites constantly bind and unbind from the DNA. As we shall see, this will lead to an effective 1D diffusion of the TF. This indicates that during the octopusing walk, the TF neither gets trapped on a single target nor fully detaches from the antenna, allowing for rapid dynamics (in fact, the 1D diffusion coefficient can be comparable to the free 3D diffusion coefficient). We shall also show that the number of bound sites on the DNA is described by a probability distribution that is in steady state and obeys detailed balance. We denote that time-dependent probability distribution of the number of bound sites by P(n,t)\begin{document}$P(n,t)$\end{document} (with n\begin{document}$n$\end{document} ranging from 0 to n~\begin{document}$\tilde{n}$\end{document}). The dynamics of this probability distribution is given by:(28)dP(n,t)dt=P(n−1,t)Wn−1,n+P(n+1,t)Wn+1,n+P(n,t)Wn,n,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{dP(n, t)}{dt}\,=\,P(n\,-\,1,t)W_{n-1,n}\,+\,P(n\,+\,1,t)W_{n+1,n}\,+\,P(n,t)W_{n,n},$$\end{document}

where W\begin{document}$W$\end{document} is called transition rate matrix, and Wn,n=−Wn,n−1−Wn,n+1\begin{document}$W_{n,n}\,=\,-W_{n,n-1}-W_{n,n+1}$\end{document}. Intuitively, we anticipate that Wn,n−1\begin{document}$W_{n,n-1}$\end{document}, corresponding to the process of detachment of one of the sites, is linear in n\begin{document}$n$\end{document}, since we expect the different sites to be approximately independent of each other. Similarly, if we consider the different IDR sites as independent ‘searchers’, the on-rate (corresponding to Wn,n+1\begin{document}$W_{n,n+1}$\end{document}) to be linear in (n~−n)\begin{document}$(\tilde{n}-n)$\end{document}. Indeed, Fig. Appendix 11—figure 1a corroborates this intuition to an excellent approximation. As the dynamics proceeds, Equation 28 would reach a steady-state distribution governed by the matrix W\begin{document}$W$\end{document}. Appendix 11—figure 1b shows the excellent agreement between the steady-state associated with the matrix W\begin{document}$W$\end{document} and that found directly from the MD simulation. This confirms that TF movement along the antenna is in a dynamic steady state. We also note that since our transition matrix is tri-diagonal, it satisfies the detailed balance condition, that is, in the steady-state reached, we have: P(n)Wn,n−1=P(n−1)Wn−1,n\begin{document}$P(n)W_{n,n-1}\,=\,P(n\,-\,1)W_{n-1,n}$\end{document}, where P(n)\begin{document}$P(n)$\end{document} is the steady-state distribution. A priori, one may think that the TF is facing two contradictory demands: on the one hand, it has to perform rapid diffusion along the DNA. On the other hand, it needs to bind sufficiently strongly so that it does not fall off the DNA too soon. Indeed, this is known as the speed-stability paradox within the context of TF search in bacteria. Importantly, the simple picture we described above explains an elegant mechanism to bypass this paradox, achieving a high diffusion coefficient with a low rate of detaching from the DNA. This comes about due to the compensatory nature of the dynamics outlined above: there is, in effect, a feedback mechanism whereby if only a few sites are attached to the DNA, the on-rate increases, and, similarly, if too many are attached (thus prohibiting the 1D diffusion), the off-rate increases. This is manifested by the peaked steady-state distribution shown in Appendix 11—figure 1b. In fact, this mechanism is remarkably effective even when the typical (i.e., most probable) number of binding sites is as small as 2 (note that in this case, as shown in the inset of Appendix 11—figure 1a, the TF may cover a distance of more than 100 bp before falling off).
